abstract.p: This study uses an experiment to examine the effects of valenced news frames, in terms of risks and benefits, on participants perceptions’ of and attitudes toward the product-country image (PCI) of “Made in China.” Findings suggest that the risks frame elicits negative perception and attitude concerning “Made in China,” whereas the benefits frame induces positive evaluations. Participants perceive the product aspect of “Made in China” more positively than the country aspect. Personal relevance, shopping experience, and shopping habit jointly affect participants’ perceptions and attitudes as covariates.

body.p: The concept of framing has been applied to a variety of communication disciplines to investigate the nature of news content or non-news messages,1 as well as their effects on audience responses.2 By highlighting a particular aspect of the societal reality in a communicating text,3 and then in the mind of the audience, the framing process can affect people’s issue perception and judgment,4 to a certain extent. Scholars argue in particular that valence framing, emphasizing either negative or positive attributes of the same object, can drive people’s thoughts in opposite directions.5

Previous studies have also suggested that people rely on media to know about foreign countries,6 and their evaluations of issues concerning remote areas are significantly affected by news framing.7 In this respect, valence framing can provide a theoretical perspective for understanding the influence of media coverage on perceptions of and attitudes toward a product-country image (PCI),8 a particular aspect regarding a given foreign nation.

The dispute over “Made in China” offers an appropriate case to assess the connection between valenced media frames and PCI concerning a specific nation, which has not received much scholarly attention. As the world’s most rapidly changing economy, China is taking major shares of global markets once dominated by the United States and other industrialized countries.9 The “Made in China” label once signified average quality and very low manufacturing cost.10 However, after the extensive pet food11 and toys recalls12 in the United States as well as a series of food safety crises occurring inside China,13 American consumers have become more and more skeptical about the quality of China-made products.14 The “Made in China” label has thus gradually become synonymous with both low cost and low quality.15

While acknowledging the relevance of PCI to strategic communication, a domain emphasizing the purposeful or planned use of communications to achieve organizational goals in areas such as public relations, advertising, and marketing communication,16 the current endeavor aims to shed light on the intersection of journalism and strategic communication, especially public relations, from a news framing perspective. Specifically, this study employs valence framing analysis in an experimental setting to test how two opposite news frames—risks and benefits—divide US audiences’ perceptions of and attitudes toward “Made in China.” The implications of the findings for mass-mediated strategic communication are also discussed.

sec.title: Valence framing
sec.p: A key concept in communication research,17 framing has been well employed in content analyses to examine how issues are depicted in news18 or non-news communication texts19 (e.g., organization’s press releases, health care messages, public service announcements, etc.) and in experimental studies to elaborate how news or message frames alter people’s cognitive responses,20 attitudes,21 and behavioral intention.22

Highlighting particular aspects of factually identical situations or objects, news or message frames are not necessarily neutral. Rather, frames may inherently hold opposite attributes. According to the prospect theory23 (often associated with the metaphor of a half-empty glass), valenced frames “are indicative of ‘good and bad’ and (implicitly) carry positive and/or negative elements.”24 Frames with positive valence emphasize beneficial or advantageous aspects, solutions, or treatments, while frames with a negative valence emphasize the opposite.

Studies on the effects of valenced frames have been well documented in various disciplines,25 where identical information was either positively or negatively presented, in terms of potential gain or loss,26 opportunity or risk,27 advantage or disadvantage,28 benefit or cost,29 to name a few. Comparing the persuasive power of valenced messages based on different types of frame manipulations30 has featured in studies with various communication contexts.31 A number of studies have suggested that valenced frames can exert sizable influence on individuals’ cognitive response32 and decision making33 regarding the issue discussed.

Valence framing is an important concept in experimental research on brand or product information for strategic communication.34 Scholars maintain, for example, that valenced frames “bias how the ads and the advertised brands are evaluated,”35 and subsequently affect people’s judgment making. In other words, an advertisement framed either positively36 or negatively37 has correspondingly favorable or unfavorable associations with the advertised product,38 and can affect people’s cognitive response,39 attitude,40 and purchasing behavior.41

Valence framing effects are also significant in studies regarding persuasive messages other than product information. Scholars argue, for instance, different valence frames lead to different degrees of effectiveness of charity advertising.42 Valence framing and other message characteristics can work together in affecting perceived value of a charity goal delivered in fundraising messages.43 Likewise, negative news that frame a corporation as practicing unethical advertising tend to elicit negative judgments on its corporate social responsibility (CSR) practices and less favorable attitudes toward the target corporation.44 While previous studies have compared persuasive effectiveness between positive and negative frames, no studies have yet connected valenced media frames with product-country image.

sec.title: Product-country image
sec.p: Derived from the discipline of international marketing,45 the construct of product-country image has been used to address the “country-of-origin (COO)” effect or “Made-in” phenomenon.46 Conceptually, PCI can be regarded as a “midpoint” between the perception of a “pure” product or brand image (e.g., “Toyota cars may not be safe to drive”) and the perception of a “pure” overall national image (e.g., “Japan is a friendly country”).

Without a uniform definition of PCI readily available in communication, this study suggests that perception of a PCI may combine two aspects—a product-related aspect (because it was “made in” a particular country) and a country-related aspect (a particular, not an overall, country image that is associated with the products)—as two sides of the same coin. In today’s globalization context, research on PCI has shown its potential to become a subject worthy of exploration in strategic communication. It can help explain the complexity of image perceptions entwined with foreign products and news coverage in domestic media.

sec.title: Media coverage and image
sec.p: Previous studies find that people without direct experience with foreign countries rely more on mass media to know about those countries.47 Scholars48 suggest that mass media play an irreplaceable role in cultivating people’s perceived image of foreign countries and that people’s evaluations of other countries are largely based on media coverage.

As for the nature of media coverage on foreign nations, Manheim and Albritton49 believe that the valence of the content is influential in altering people’s perception of foreign countries. In the long run, a country’s image created by the media can be improved or impaired depending on whether positive outweighs negative media coverage, or vice versa.50 This notion regarding the nature as well as the influence of media coverage on the formation of an overall national image is pertinent to the question of how media shape a product-country image. Media coverage on foreign products may likewise influence people’s perceptions of and attitudes toward a given product-country image.

sec.title: “Made in China.”
sec.p: “Made in China” literally refers to the label affixed to products manufactured in Mainland China.51 Today, with China being the largest manufacturer and exporter of consumer goods in the world, “Made in China” has become one of the most recognizable labels.52 For companies outsourcing manufacturing to China, “Made in China” stands for low cost of labor and resources and also competitive advantages; for consumers, before the series of product safety scandals, “Made in China” represented value for money,53 or at least average quality at low cost.54

With the safety of China-made goods at concern, consumers are becoming apprehensive about buying “Made in China,” and many companies are considering outsourcing manufacturing to countries other than China.55 In addition, China’s regulations of product quality, intellectual property rights issues, human rights record, and trade disputes with the United States have all contributed to the recent “Made in China” crisis56 and drawn attention to this particular product-country image.

sec.title: Valence framing and PCI
sec.p: It is noteworthy that literature about “Made in China” is scanty in the communication discipline. Only a few studies analyze strategic communication about products made in China. For example, Cai, Lee, and Pang57 discuss the image-repairing strategies adopted by the Chinese government following product recalls in 2007. Li and Tang58 examine how national and local newspapers in the United States framed Chinese product recalls in 2007. They argue that Chinese sources are less likely to be cited by American media for their non-US perspectives. No research has assessed framing effects of media coverage on audiences’ perceptions and attitudes in terms of product-country image.

Although the aforementioned valence of “image” coverage59 refers to the “extrinsic” feature of news stories, not the valence of news frames imbedded in the coverage, this study argues that a product-country image should be the outcome of a summarized perception cultivated and influenced by the framed messages underlying media coverage. In other words, it is the valence of relevant news frames that determines the valence or tone of the coverage on the products made in a given country, from which a biased perception may result. As a corollary, valenced frames are likely to affect people’s perceived PCI, then lead to frame-consistent evaluations. Analyzing frame attributes thus provides a better understanding of the PCI woven by mass media and perceived by the public.

Applying the notion of valence framing, the present study aims to compare the effect of risks frame and benefits frame on people’s perceptions of and attitudes toward “Made in China.” The risks frame focuses on the negative aspects concerning products made in China, such as product safety, US trade deficit and unemployment in the manufacturing sector, and human rights concerns. The benefits frame highlights the positive aspects of using and marketing China-made products, such as affordability, improved quality, rising of Chinese brands, and US economic gains from trading with China.

sec.title: Hypotheses and Research Questions
sec.p: Based on the literature review, this study proposes the first two sets of hypotheses to test the valence framing effect on perceptions.

list-item.p: H1a: Framing “Made in China” in terms of risks will lead to negative perception of the product aspect of this PCI.
H1b: Framing “Made in China” in terms of risks will lead to negative perception of the country aspect of this PCI.
H2a: Framing “Made in China” in terms of benefits will lead to positive perception of the product aspect of this PCI.
H2b: Framing “Made in China” in terms of benefits will lead to positive perception of the country aspect of this PCI.

sec.p: Meanwhile, drawing upon evidence regarding the effects of valence framing on attitudes from previous studies,60 we assume that valence frames not only influence people’s perceptions, but also affect their attitudes toward “Made in China.” This argument is addressed in the third set of hypotheses.

list-item.p: H3a: Framing “Made in China” in terms of risks will draw negative attitudes toward this PCI.
H3b: Framing “Made in China” in terms of benefits will draw positive attitudes toward this PCI.

sec.p: In addition, prior studies61 suggest personal experience plays a weighty role in the formation of certain national images. Product involvement and personal relevance62 also affect message processing in brand evaluation. The present study argues that personal experience embraces psychological and behavioral aspects. The former refers to personal relevance (e.g., curiosity, interest) due to personal involvement in the subject concerned; the latter is related to particular activities, including shopping experience and habit. We incorporate personal relevance and prior shopping behavior into the analysis as covariates. The following two research questions are then raised:

list-item.p: RQ1: To what extent will personal relevance, in terms of the level of personal involvement in China-related matters, affect perceptions of and attitudes toward the product-country image of “Made in China”?
RQ2: To what extent will shopping habit and experience of buying and using China-made products affect perceptions of and attitudes toward the product-country image of “Made in China”?

sec.title: Design
sec.p: This study adopted a single-factor, posttest only, between-subjects experimental design. Following previous experimental research with a similar focus on comparing two competing stimuli,63 this study did not use a pretest in order to avoid possible subject sensitization to the posttest. Three conditions were included in the design. One represented risks frame, another benefits frame, and the third the control condition. The inclusion of a control condition both in design and analysis allowed the current study to compare the possible difference not only between opposite frame valences, but also between news facts with and without valenced frames. This marked one of the differences between the current project and relevant previous experimental research.64

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: One hundred and eighty American undergraduate students taking mass communication courses at a large Midwest university volunteered to participate in this study. Among the participants, 27% were male and 73% female. No Chinese students were included. Upon completion of the test, participants received extra credit and were entered for a prize draw.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The experiment was conducted in February 2010. Participants were randomly assigned to each of the three conditions. They first answered questions related to demographics and consumer behavior. Next, they read an experimentally prepared news story before completing the remaining part of the questionnaire measuring their perceptions of and attitudes toward “Made in China,” and their personal relevance with China-related matters. After completing the questionnaire, the participants were debriefed. The entire procedure lasted about forty minutes.

sec.title: Stimulus materials
sec.p: Three news stories were prepared for the experimental and control conditions. The original news article, taken from the New York Times, was about US public concerns over the safety and quality of products made in China. It was rewritten in three versions to correspond to three conditions. Each included the same core information describing the basic facts relevant to an opinion poll. The font, layout, and general appearance of these versions were identical. They all gave the impression of being from the New York Times.

For each of the two framing conditions, the title, introductory and concluding paragraphs, and supporting messages were rewritten in similar length and style, but emphasized different aspects of the basic facts to establish opposite frames. The benefits-framed article was titled “While China Steps up Safety Efforts, Americans Benefit, Poll Finds,” and the risks-framed article was titled “China’s Safety Efforts in Doubt and Americans at Risk, Poll Finds.” For the control condition, the article had the title “Americans Have Mixed Feelings about Chinese Goods, Poll Finds” and mainly presented the core factual information.

All three articles were carefully reviewed and revised by a native English speaker, who is a former journalist and currently a faculty member in mass communication at an East Coast university. To ensure successful message manipulations, all stimuli were pilot-tested with thirty randomly assigned participants who would not be included in the test. Three groups of ten participants each were asked to read one story corresponding to one of the three conditions and then answer two questions about whether the news covered China-made products as well as China in a positive versus negative light on a 5-point Likert scale. The result confirmed successful manipulation: the two experimental conditions were sufficiently strong to allow difference in dependent measures between the framed conditions as well as between framed conditions and the control condition.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Perceptions of “Made in China” refer to the cognitive attributes and mental images that participants hold regarding both product aspect65 and country aspect66 of “Made in China,” and were measured by multiple items on a 5-point scale ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree. After reverse coding, two composite indices were constructed by averaging the item values to represent the product-related perceptions of “Made in China” (α = .81, M = 3.23, SD = .50) and the country-related perceptions (α = .85, M = 2.85, SD = .58). Higher scores indicated more positive perceptions.

Attitudes toward “Made in China” refer to participants’ evaluation of or judgment on the China-made products and relevant issues, and were measured by ten items on a 5-point scale.67 A composite index was constructed by averaging the multi-item values after reverse coding (α = .85, M = 3.13, SD = .45). Higher scores stood for more positive attitudes.

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: (1) Personal relevance was measured by five items on a 5-point scale.68 The item scores were averaged to range from 1 to 5 (α = .73, M = 2.56, SD = .66) with 1 as not personally relevant at all and 5 as highly relevant. (2) Shopping habit was measured by four items on a 5-point scale (α = .77, M = 3.34, SD = .86),69 where 1 suggested that participants did not care about the origin of products or brands at all, and 5 suggested they were very careful about where the product came from. (3) Shopping experience was measured by three items on a 5-point scale, with 1 as strongly disagree, and 5 as strongly agree regarding the statements.70 The item scores were averaged to range from 1 to 5 (α = .79, M = 4.16, SD = .55). Higher scores indicated more experience in buying or using China-made products.

sec.title: Manipulation check
sec.p: ANOVA reports a successful experimental manipulation. Those exposed to the framed news coverage rated the product aspect (risks: M = 1.72, SD = .67; benefits: M = 3.82, SD = .81) and country aspect (risks: M = 2.03, SD = .71; benefits: M = 3.93, SD = .74) of “Made in China” as expected. The two experimental conditions are also significantly different from the control condition; product aspect: M = 2.31, SD= .71, F (2, 176) = 129.43, p < .001; country aspect: M = 2.57, SD = .71, F (2, 175) = 108.74, p < .001.

sec.title: Framing effects on perceptions of “Made in China.”
sec.p: H1a and H1b predict that participants in the risks condition will have more negative perceptions of the product-country image than those in the benefits condition and in the control condition. H2a and H2b expect the opposite result, where benefits-framed news will draw more positive perceptions than those either in the risks or control condition. Table 1 shows the means of the three conditions to be significantly different. Therefore, H1a, H1b, H2a, and H2b are all supported.

fn.p: Post hoc tests reveal significant pairwise mean differences among conditions (product aspect: risks vs. benefits, p < .001; risks vs. control, p < .05; benefits vs. control, p < .01; country aspect: risks vs. benefits, p < .001; risks vs. control, p < .05; benefits vs. control, p < .001).

fn.label: b
fn.p: Post hoc tests confirm a significant pairwise mean difference between risks and benefits conditions (p < .01).

sec.title: Framing effects on attitudes toward “Made in China.”
sec.p: H3a and H3b propose that valenced frames can also induce frame-consistent attitudes toward “Made in China.” Although the mean difference between the control and the two experimental conditions are not significant, the two experimental conditions are significantly different, as shown in Table 1. Therefore, H3a and H3b are partially supported.

sec.title: Influence of covariates
sec.p: ANCOVA (in Table 2) tests for the simultaneous influence of personal relevance, shopping experience, shopping habit, and experimental stimulus. Parameter estimates indicate that the individual effects of the covariates are significant in the expected direction, except for shopping habit. Both personal relevance (product aspect: r = .18, p < .05; b = .17, p < .01; country aspect: r =.23, p < .01; b = .21, p < .01) and shopping experience (product aspect: r = .45, p < .01; b = .36; p < .001; country aspect: r =. 24, p < .01; b = .15, p < .05) positively correlate with the formation of product-country image, controlling for experimental conditions. With the coefficients taken into account, personal relevance explains more variance in the country aspect than in the product aspect, while shopping experience accounts for the product aspect better. Comparing the magnitudes of influence between the two covariates, we notice that shopping experience is more powerful than personal relevance concerning the product aspect, whereas the latter is stronger than the former with regard to the country aspect. Meanwhile, the main effect of exposure to framed news remains the most powerful factor according to the partial eta2 value, confirming the ANOVA findings.

caption.p: ANCOVA on Perceptions of “Made in China”

sec.p: As for the influence of covariates on attitudes toward “Made in China,” Table 3 highlights the significance of prior shopping behavior. In terms of correlation and b coefficients, shopping experience (r = .31, p < .01; b = .19, p < .01) and shopping habit (r = .29, p < .01; b = .12, p < .01) exert similar influence on the attitudinal outcome, controlling for the experimental conditions. This result illustrates the positive association between prior shopping behavior and the formation of attitudes toward “Made in China.”

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Furthering the conversations of previous research about valence framing effects in various communication disciplines,71 this study pays particular attention to the relationship between valenced media frames and the product-country image of “Made in China.” Although the notion of PCI and the specific case discussed readily aligns this study with public relations, our test on the effects of media frames connects journalism and strategic communication as well. Resonating prior experimental studies, the current project supports the notion that valenced frames have the capacity to alter people’s perceptions of and attitudes toward a certain subject matter.72 It may contribute to the literature on the role of media in forming and fashioning image perceptions and attitudes as well as on the application of quantitative framing analysis in strategic communication scholarship.

Showcasing the valence framing effect on people’s perceptions of a particular PCI, this study first confirms that the news framed with risks elicits negative perceptions concerning both the product aspect and the country aspect of “Made in China,” while the news framed with benefits induces positive perceptions. Findings then indicate that participants perceive the product aspect of “Made in China” more positively than the country aspect. While the latter is mainly associated with negative elements such as trade deficit and unemployment in the United States, and human rights concerns in China, the former is mixed with both negative (e.g., safety concern, poor quality) and positive messages (e.g., affordability, availability). As Americans in general use China-made products almost every day, when a negatively framed message about those products is at work, participants are likely to take personal experience73 and product attributes into account as well, which may offset the framing effect to some extent. As a result, participants do not rate very negatively the products they use often. On the contrary, when positive evaluation is induced by positively framed news, participants intend to make cue-based judgments.74 In this sense, the framed message can direct, but not control, the ideas and feelings activated when people process news stories.75

This argument is further verified when covariates figure in the process. A higher level of personal involvement dilutes the influence of a negative frame and switches people’s thoughts toward a more positive perception. At the same time, those who have already consumed China-made goods are also inclined to process “Made in China” along a positive line. Further, shopping experience is stronger than personal relevance in activating immediate cognitive response or impression concerning the product aspect, whereas the latter was more powerful regarding the country aspect.

As for the contrast between the experiment conditions and the control condition, it is no surprise that framed messages show stronger influence than unframed messages in forming image perception. This result suggests, however, that messages without a valenced frame tend to have a “neutralizing” effect that directed participants’ perceptions to the “middle point” along the negative-positive spectrum.

Regarding the attitudes toward “Made in China,” this study partially confirms that valenced media frames can also draw frame-consistent attitudes toward PCI. Post hoc tests suggest that the two experimental conditions are significantly different one from the other, although no significant mean differences are found between the control condition and the two experimental conditions. This result defends the expectation that news frames can play an important role in forming people’s short-term attitudes. Meanwhile, in the complicated cognitive process, participants in the control condition may rely on their prior existing schema to automatically activate associated evaluations,76 which may naturally lead to an inclination for either more positive or more negative attitudes in this case.

Moreover, regarding the influence of covariates, attitudes are positively correlated with prior shopping behavior but not with personal relevance. Those who pay no heed to the brand or country origin of products, along with those who have used Chinese goods, show more positive attitudes toward “Made in China.” A possible reason is that shopping experience and habits can develop over time, and may have already been incorporated into participants’ existing schema, which is readily available to become more decisive when later attitudinal judgment on a related issue must be made.

Although this study does not address the valence framing effect directly on product promotion or international marketing communication, the findings about media framing of PCI have practical implications for strategic communicators. On one hand, as previous research suggests, strategic preparation of public relations message is crucial to obtaining effective outcome favoring an organization.77 Communicators may structure the message by properly and purposely incorporating a certain angle of an issue to facilitate positive perceptions or attitudes. On the other hand, communications do not always occur between an organization and key publics directly; rather, today’s media still play a big role in between. An image can be improved in media and consequently better received by the target public.78 As the first step to achieve this objective, communicators should position themselves as frame strategists and consider how valenced media frames can determine the nature of a certain issue, and why the framed news information can be accepted or rejected by the public who “have different positions”79 on the issue. With a better understanding of media frames, strategic communicators may help alter negative perception or cultivate favorable opinion toward the products made in a certain country through mass communication.

Furthermore, although elaborating the linkage between PCI and the overall national image goes beyond the scope of this article, it is noteworthy that PCI can serve as “the building blocks of the general image” of a country,80 which in return affect people’s evaluation of the products made in that country. In this regard, investigating valenced media frames of PCI is helpful to countries that intend to expand their overseas markets. Consider again the “Made in China” case. Although Chinese government and manufacturers have made great efforts to deal with the product recall crises, their communication with the public in international markets by targeting an instant turnaround has yet to be effective.81 Rather negative frames have for a while drawn considerable concern among the public not only about specific Chinese products, but also about other issues regarding that country. If there is any lesson to learn, strategic communicators in a country of origin should pay serious attention to the PCI depicted in international media82 and consider how to get positive messages across to target consumers there through media to build up a healthy overall national image that is related, but not restricted, to particular products.

Framing “Made in China” in risks and benefits may have “ignored” other “aspects and particularities” of this issue.83 However, based on the theoretical grounds established by previous studies,84 we argue that negative (risks) versus positive (benefits) frames are intrinsic to the topic regarding “Made in China,” considering the difficult balance stakeholders always try to strike between product quality and cost, and, broadly, imports and exports in international trade, along with people’s mixed feelings about buying Chinese products. As an initial effort toward connecting news framing effects with PCI literature, this study may also facilitate an appreciation of the pertinence of information processing approach to the scholarship on image or reputation in strategic communication.

sec.title: Limitations and future research
sec.p: While offering intriguing findings, the limitations of this study should be noted for further discussion. First, the current experiment prepared one example of risks or benefits frame, which restrains the generalizability of the findings. Future studies can test multiple scenarios of risks or benefits to compare the results drawn from different manipulations. Second, due to the nature of experimental study, participants are often recruited from a group of students enrolled in a certain study program in college, with possible gender imbalance.85 The participants’ profile of this study reflects this feature, which may affect the external validity of the findings. Recognizing this weakness, we should regard the findings as tentative and be cautious to generalize to all American consumers or the general population. Third, the items used to measure the variables were developed particularly for the current study based on our content analysis of US media coverage on China-made goods, with inspirations from several previous studies reviewed in the aforementined on image86 and “Made in China.”87 Although the measuring instruments yielded reliable Cronbach’s alpha values and satisfying content validity, they can be further refined in future research to ensure construct validity. Fourth, future research is needed to investigate the valence framing effect on perceived place-of-origin image or overall national image that may emerge from the valence-framed news coverage of PCI in order to draw a clearer picture of the formation and hierarchy of image perception in mass-mediated strategic communication process.
